awd_titl_txt: EAGER: New possibilities for broadening the impacts of middle school engineering through a partnership between teachers and underrepresented minority engineering college students
awd_abstract_narration:
Many schools include engineering design tasks in the science curriculum as one way to provide opportunities for middle school students to contribute to finding solutions to real-world problems. However, students who attend high needs schools often have few opportunities to make such contributions. This condition exists because sometimes teachers in high needs schools have difficulty creating learning environments where students feel confident enough to engage in the engineering design process. This exploratory project will address this issue by looking at whether pairing middle school teachers with undergraduate engineering students increases teachers' capacity to create this type of learning environment. It will use a collaborative incubator model to examine pair interactions and document when and under what conditions knowledge creation and transfer might take place. The study will address a gap in the literature where few studies have expressly looked at the use of undergraduate engineers from this viewpoint. It will initiate the development of a pathway towards a deeper understanding about how to improve teachers' knowledge and skills such that they can implement these types of activities on their own. 

A case study design will capture information about the project through interviews, classroom observations, videos, audio recordings, and think-aloud protocols. Information from these data sources will advance understanding regarding prior experiences, individual beliefs and approaches about facilitating engineering design tasks in high needs schools. Different strategies for analyzing data will be used to establish a baseline for teachers and undergraduate engineering students to maximize potential growth with respect to the design process through pairing of the study subjects. Specifically, discourse analysis will be used to code instances when tacit knowledge of pair members combines to produce scaffolding questions and directions that promote creative problem solving during each stage of the design process. This step will also be used to corroborate verbal profile analysis and select cases that highlight exemplary collaborations between teachers and undergraduate engineering students. It will further help track changes in culture, language, and norms within the pairing over time. Outcomes will include information about whether meaningful transfer of knowledge and skills might occur within teacher-engineering student pairing in contextually rich ways that inform change at the classroom level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Overview and Outcomes

This exploratory study examined how STEM undergraduate mentors of color collaborated with secondary science and mathematics teachers in high need schools to facilitate the engineering design process as a tool for teaching core ideas and practices. Fifty collaborations between undergradutes and secondary teachers occurred over the duration of the project in a large urban district in Virginia. This included 11 face-to face collaborations during an academic year, 12 virtual collaborations with classes during the Covid-19 pandemic, and 27 face-to-face collaborations with students in summer school classrooms with a focus on STEM enrichment. These collaborations have directly served approximately 1063 students who are predominately African American and from low-income households. 

A variety of data was collected on collaborations that included interviews and focus groups with teachers and undergraduate mentors, classroom observations, recordings of collaborative planning meetings between undergraduate mentors and teachers, and lesson plans/curricular materials generated from the collaborations. Secondary data was also collected on how students communicated with mentors in person and online using digital technologies, as well as students' engagement in the engineering design process, and meeting notes between the PI and the school district to support collaborations between mentors and teachers.

The collaborations between undergraduate students and teachers received support from district STEM leaders, who engaged both groups in joint professional development. The purpose was to help them better understand how to incorporate the engineering design process into science and mathematics classrooms. To facilitate this process, the Principal Investigator (PI) and STEM specialists from the school district developed online engineering design notebooks. These digital platforms allowed teachers and undergraduates to seamlessly integrate standards-based science and mathematics activities and offer real-time feedback. Furthermore, the team also created model engineering design notebooks for teachers and undergraduates, with a focus on encouraging students to effectively communicate their science ideas and engineering practices during challenges. In addition, district specialists organized meetings and opportunities for undergraduates and teachers to collaborate on adapting personalized engineering notebooks for use across various secondary-level classrooms.

This work has yielded numerous publications and conference presentations that highlight the unique contributions of undergraduate mentors of color. These contributions included the development of real-world applications of science and engineering, the integration of computer science and coding with engineering, and the sharing of personal narratives that humanize the fields of science and engineering (Kier & Johnson, 2021). Our findings revealed that teachers who placed value on student collaboration, viewed engineering as a tool to address community and societal issues, prioritized diverse representation in the classrooms, and emphasized relationship-building were the most successful in promoting students' engagement and fostering connections to the fields of engineering, mathematics, and science (Kier & Johnson, 2021).

This work also led to ten research experiences in collaboration between the Principal Investigator (PI) and undergraduate mentors, who were interested in studying the dynamics of collaboration between teachers and students and the resulting outcomes. Through virtual observations of classrooms and collaboration meetings, we observed that undergraduates and teachers effectively utilized digital tools provided by the district to facilitate communication and design learning opportunities, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic (Kier & Johnson, 2022). Additionally, our research found that collaborations between teachers and mentors in summer school settings had a positive impact on students' engagement and interest in STEM, as well as their connection to a mentor in the STEM field (Johnson et al., 2023). Furthermore, students' written communication with teachers and the content found in undergraduate notebooks provide valuable insights into how teachers can enhance the integration of engineering and technology into science and mathematics practices (Kier & Hardner, under review).

Crucially, this study has identified that STEM undergraduate mentors of color offer valuable insights for promoting culturally relevant teaching and enhancing programs designed to support youth from marginalized backgrounds in STEM (Kier et al., work in progress). Furthermore, the mentors have shared insightful reflections on how their engagement with secondary students has contributed to their own growth as future STEM professionals (Kier, work in progress) and assisted them in navigating their personal experiences of being marginalized within the STEM field (Martinez-Campa & Kier, under review).

In addition to the professional development materials and research findings generated by this study, our efforts have fostered a dedicated partnership between the William & Mary School of Education and the local urban school district. This partnership aims to sustain ongoing programs that involve collaborations between undergraduate mentors of color and STEM teachers in various formal and informal STEM learning environments.
